searchDocs.content: 1 Kings 11:1 is the original Mambo No. 5. üòÜ

searchDocs.title: 1 Kings 13 & Psalm 94
searchDocs.content: Perhaps Psalm 94:1 and the rest of the Psalm are two sides of the same coin? This seems to be the Psalmist taking hold of the promise/command in Deut 32:35 that Paul quotes in Romans 12 and also the writer of Hebrews (Vengeance is mine, I will repay, says the Lord). Paul pairs this with radical love for enemies, apparently because vengeance is the Lord‚Äôs job, not ours. Yet our Lord himself said ‚ÄúFather, forgive them...‚Äù In this Psalm, concern seems to be for the widow, orphan, and immigrant who are killed by people who are the target of the Psalmist‚Äôs prayer for vengeance. There are a lot of good tensions and plenty of working out of justice and radical love, costly forgiveness, and reconciliation in this wonderful book we‚Äôre reading.

searchDocs.title: 1 Kings 20-22 & Psalm 100
searchDocs.content: When things are strange in the Bible, it‚Äôs a clue it might be important... what‚Äôs up with prophets cursing other prophets so that they are killed by a lion? RE: the "lying spirit", this is a divine council throne room scene like the beginning of Job where Yahweh gets input from other heavenly beings. The similarities are that many heavenly beings are there with Yahweh ruling over them and that he raises a human as the topic of discussion, with someone proposing a course of actions to be taken against him. The differences are that in Job, "the satan" (literally "the adversary" and translated as such in other places, but here often translated as a proper name ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è ) is the other heavenly being in focus, whereas here in 1 Kings it is a non-specific spirit. In Job, the satan suggests harming the man Job after Yahweh extols him; here, Yahweh specifically asks for help enticing Ahab to go to battle so that he dies. In Job, the narrator directly sets the divine council scene; here, the narrator has the prophet Micaiah narrate a vision of this heavenly scene playing out. Here, there seems to be a tight alignment of obedience of the heavenly beings to Yahweh on the throne even though there seems to first be a debate about how to accomplish Yahweh‚Äôs goal of enticing Ahab. Interestingly, Yahweh approves of this divine lying.

searchDocs.title: 1 Kings 8-10 & Psalm 96
searchDocs.content: I‚Äôve heard some scholars dismiss a link between Solomon‚Äôs income of 666 talents of gold and the mark of the beast in Revelation, but I still wonder about it, with all the overlaps about buying, selling, and trade. The author in 1 Kings 10 is being intentional about describing Solomon's wealth and him doing all the things from Deuteronomy 17 that a king shouldn't do.

searchDocs.title: 1 Samuel 15-17 & Psalm 82
searchDocs.content: One of the best stories in the Bible. Goliath‚Äôs armor is noted as ‚Äúbronze‚Äù 4 times (sounds like ‚Äúsnake‚Äù in Hebrew) and has ‚Äúscale‚Äù armor üêç And David strikes his head and then uses Goliath‚Äôs own weapon against him. Genesis 3:15 üí• When Saul was selected by lot he was oddly found hiding among the baggage. Here David boldly leaves the baggage to fight Goliath. So... as king, Saul came with a lot of baggage? ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è üòÇ Psalm 82:11 says that God judges in the midst of the gods (i.e. not humans here). Only a few versions I see still translate this as ‚Äúrulers,‚Äù maybe because of worries it doesn‚Äôt seem ‚Äúmonotheistic.‚Äù But the Bible seems consistent in a worldview that other gods exist, but there are none like Yahweh, the LORD. I‚Äôm convinced by arguments that it‚Äôs more straightforward, then, in v6-7 that those gods are being addressed and judged for not ruling justly as listed in v2-5. v8 is part of why I‚Äôm convinced: Arise God, judge the earth, for you shall possess all the nations. What does the judgment against the gods have to do with God possessing all the nations? Note ‚Äúsons of the Most High‚Äù in v6, then, related, Deut 32:8-9 Moses referring to the Tower of Babel and table of 70 nations: ‚ÄúWhen the Most High gave the nations their inheritance, When he separated the sons of adam, He set the boundaries of the peoples according to the sons of elohim. For the Lord‚Äôs portion is his people; Jacob is the allotment of his inheritance.‚Äù The argument is that Deut 32 is God giving the nations to the gods, but Israel to himself, and Psalm 82 is about God reclaiming all the nations when those gods ruled them unjustly. This was not something I expected to see in my Bible, but I‚Äôve become convinced that it‚Äôs probably what it is saying.

searchDocs.title: 1 Samuel 18-20 & Psalm 83
searchDocs.content: Jonathan to me seems to be portrayed as both a good neighbor and like a good brother. He is said to love David as he loves himself. And when David‚Äôs life is at stake, they go out into the field (like Cain and Abel)--"Come, let us go out to the field"--but Jonathan saves David‚Äôs life there with the secret arrow code.

searchDocs.title: 1 Samuel 21-24 & Psalm 84
searchDocs.content: David to Saul after he had the chance to kill Saul but didn‚Äôt is a wonderful example of leaving vengeance to God and trusting him for his safety and future: ‚ÄúMay the Lord judge between you and me, and may the Lord take vengeance on you for me; but my hand shall not be against you... May the Lord therefore be judge and decide between you and me; and may He see and plead my cause and save me from your hand.‚Äù This is a good statement for me to meditate on some more. It seems like this attitude is reflected in many Psalms.

searchDocs.title: 1 Samuel 25-27 & Psalm 85
searchDocs.content: I love the Nabal/David/Abigail story. For me it‚Äôs interesting how not not lifting a finger against the Lord‚Äôs anointed (Saul) is a big moral line for David, even when attacked, but he flies into a rage against Nabal and almost murders his household when disrespected and unfairly denied food for his men. Hebrew help? Footnote with David‚Äôs threat to kill all the "males" belonging to Nabal gives me the impression he‚Äôs being vulgar in his rage, calling them something like "wall-pissers". Does this kind of language show up anywhere else? Abigail‚Äôs words are exquisite in calming David down. From Allen: I think you're on to something -- the phrase "one who urinates on a wall" shows up 6 times in the OT. 1 Sam. 25:22, 34; 1 Ki. 14:10; 16:11; 21:21; and 2 Ki. 9:8. Always in the context of a discussion of wiping out a whole group of men or family. It definitely has a strongly-worded feel to it -- the best dictionary for biblical Hebrew (HALOT) says this of the phrase: "contemptuous expression for masculinity". That's saying it nicely. üôÇ

searchDocs.title: 2 Kings 1-3 & Psalm 101
searchDocs.content: I‚Äôm confused by 3:27. Looking back at what Elisha says to the king of Israel, he scoffs and tells him to go to Ahab‚Äôs and Jezebel‚Äôs false prophets and "As surely as the Lord of armies lives, before whom I stand, if I did not respect Jehoshaphat the king of Judah, I would not look at you nor see you." It seems like Israel only gets help because the king of Judah is with them? The "great anger" only comes upon Israel, but not Judah. Is Israel without the protection of Yahweh from Moab‚Äôs god?

searchDocs.title: 2 Samuel 1-3 & Psalm 87
searchDocs.content: The second Samuel scroll resumes with all the staples of a good story. Fighting, mourning, games of thrones, civil war, odd specifics of pursuit and hand to hand combat, revenge, and betrayal. But there seems to be more here that I can‚Äôt put my finger on. This seems to be one of those parts of the Bible that is doing something to me subconsciously; come for the movie, stay of the sermon... but surprise, the movie was the sermon, and I don‚Äôt understand how. At least one thing that seemed to rise to the surface was the meaninglessness of the deaths in the civil war. The first 12 against 12 all quickly kill themselves similtaneously. A quick footed young man dies chasing down an experienced older man who finally gets everyone to cool it saying ‚ÄúShould the sword devour forever? Do you not realize that it will be bitter in the end?‚Äù In ch1 an interesting word play: the Amalekite who reports to David the death of Saul comes with dust on his head, then dies with David saying his blood is on his own head because his own mouth testified against him. ‚ÄúDust‚Äù is literally ‚Äúground‚Äù (Heb adamah) on his head subbed for blood (Heb dam) on his head. Anything going on here with Gen 4 and the ‚Äúadamah‚Äù opening its mouth to receive Abel‚Äôs ‚Äúdam‚Äù from Cain‚Äôs hand? Is this a hint that David‚Äôs judgment on him was not just?

searchDocs.title: 2 Samuel 9-12 & Psalm 89
searchDocs.content: We haven‚Äôt had too many outright declarations of ‚Äúand what he did was evil in the sight of the Lord‚Äù but David‚Äôs adultery/murder gets it. Joab, who had murdered Abner in vengeance, participates in the conspiracy and uses David‚Äôs secret to his political advantage to cover his mistake. David‚Äôs response to the collateral damage: war kills people ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è What a warning about how easy it is for power/money/position to make us feel better than and dehumanize others. Wow. üëç Rahab in Psalm 89:10 is a common word for Egypt portrayed as a sea monster (mirroring the prior verse). In English it looks the same as Rahab from Jericho but in Hebrew they are spelled differently, for the same reason it‚Äôs spelled both Hanukkah and Chanukkah in English.

searchDocs.title: 2 Samuel 13-15 & Psalm 90
searchDocs.content: As Nathan declared, the sword doesn‚Äôt depart from David‚Äôs house; it‚Äôs also mixed with tragedies due to sexual sin as with David. As the true shoot of Jesse, I‚Äôm sure Jesus had this warning in his heart when he said ‚ÄúThose who take the sword will perish by the sword‚Äù In our peaceful corner of the globe, I‚Äôm not having to resist violence right now. But I‚Äôm challenged by how much these very human stories of sexual sin and violent sin are enmeshed and how a beautiful means of life can become death when seeing/taking what is good in one‚Äôs own eyes. When Absalom tells his men to kill Amnon in revenge (2 years later... very cold revenge) he sounds like Joshua (Joshua 1:9) ‚ÄúDo not fear; have I not commanded you myself? Be courageous and be valiant.‚Äù But he‚Äôs not telling them to meditate on the Torah like Joshua was. Good thing politicians don‚Äôt use Bible language to justify violence anymore üò¨

searchDocs.title: Deuteronomy 17-20 & Psalm 59
searchDocs.content: The list of restrictions (17:16) for future kings is interesting: Don‚Äôt acquire lots of horsesDon‚Äôt make people return to Egypt to get horsesDon‚Äôt acquire many wivesDon‚Äôt greatly increase in gold/silver Solomon will break all 4 of these. Also (17:18) a king is supposed to make their own copy of the Torah to keep and read daily to keep him humble. Imagine if political leaders read scripture with an eye toward staying humble and not enriching themselves üò¨ 18:15 an Israelite prophet like Moses is coming. Who will it be? ‚ÄúTo him you shall listen.‚Äù Remember what the voice from the cloud said at the Transfiguration.

searchDocs.title: Deuteronomy 28-39 & Psalm 62
searchDocs.content: 29:29: "The secret things belong to the Lord our God, but the things revealed belong to us and to our sons forever, so that we may follow all the words of this Law." I could do a lot more thinking about this.

searchDocs.title: Deuteronomy 4-6 & Psalm 54
searchDocs.content: Moses seems to be saying the Lord gave the nations the heavenly hosts? (4:19) Is Paul working with this worldview in Acts 17:29-31 saying the time for that is over with Jesus? In 5:3-4 is the emphasis of ‚Äúdid not make this covenant with our fathers, but with us‚Äù on the distinction between the people of the Exodus and the patriarchs? 5:11 Now that I‚Äôve heard Dr. Carmen Imes explain ‚Äúbearing‚Äù the Lord‚Äôs name, the translation ‚Äútake the name... in vain‚Äù seems so impoverished. Ps 54:4 God is my ‚Äúhelper‚Äù is the same word in Gen 2:18 ‚Äúhelper corresponding to [the man]‚Äù Also Dr Imes: this kind of helper is ‚Äúnot someone to make you sandwiches‚Äù üòÇ

searchDocs.title: 2 Samuel 4-8 & Psalm 88
searchDocs.content: The ‚Äúdiscipline [your seed] with a rod of men and with strokes of the sons of adam, but my favor shall not depart from him‚Äù is quite striking, pun not intended.

searchDocs.title: 2 Samuel 16-18 & Psalm 91
searchDocs.content: 16:23 seems to be an addendum to the story to explain the general persuasion of Ahithophel‚Äôs advice. ‚ÄúIn those days‚Äù is the same phrase (both English and Hebrew) as at the end of Judges (‚ÄúIn those days there was no king in Israel...‚Äù) This seems to be a warning both against misusing spiritual trust/authority and against being taken in by such misuse. I‚Äôm surprised by how many sage warnings are embedded in Samuel relevant today to church and power. When Absalom gets stuck in the tree, the language seems carefully chosen: ‚Äúhe was placed between the heavens and the earth.‚Äù He‚Äôs portrayed as cursed (from Deut. ‚ÄúCursed is anyone who is hanged on a tree‚Äù) and pierced through the heart. Maybe Paul in Gal 3:13 has both Absalom and Ahithophel in mind for the shame/curse Jesus endured? Apparently Absalom means ‚Äúfather (God) is peace.‚Äù This is ironic since Absalom embodies the opposite of peace, along with his statement recorded at the end of his story ‚ÄúI have no son‚Äù?

searchDocs.title: Exodus 4-6 & Psalm 18
searchDocs.content: Moses brings up his speech problems twice. Interesting thing pointed out to me recently: Zipporah is the last of 7 women at the beginning of Exodus that save Moses, the Exodus, and the covenant: Shiphrah, Puah (midwives), Moses‚Äô mom and sister (put him in the Nile), Pharaoh‚Äôs daughter and servant (draw him out), and Zipporah. I think the narrator gives us the truncated genealogy to root the priesthood in the tribe of Levi, but not sure why Reuben and Simeon get mentioned first, except that these are the first 3 sons of Jacob in birth order. The Lord to Moses: ‚ÄúGo back to Egypt, for all the men who were seeking your life are dead.‚Äù In Matthew 2 an angel tells Joseph to go back ‚Äúto the land of Israel, for those who sought the child‚Äôs life are dead.‚Äù Matthew with some harsh criticism for how Egypt-like Israel had become. I‚Äôm constantly amazed at how realistic the Hebrew scriptural tradition is, pointing out their society‚Äôs own failings.

searchDocs.title: Exodus 1-3 & Psalm 17
searchDocs.content: So many Genesis bits showing up in the beginning of Exodus. The sons of Israel being fruitful and multiplying and ‚Äúswarming‚Äù (Gen 1).Come let us deal shrewdly (üêç)Mortar and bricks (tower in Babylon)Moses in the ‚Äúbasket‚Äù same word as the ‚Äúark‚Äùof the flood and pitched with pitch to rescue from the water of death. Deuteronomy 4:12 (Then the Lord spoke to you from the midst of the fire; you heard the sound of words, but you saw no form‚Äîthere was only a voice) This fire is the one the people saw at the mountain. But apparently Moses saw some kind of human form in the burning bush (?), since ‚Äúthe angel of the Lord appeared to him in a blazing fire from the midst of the bush‚Äù in other words, he saw the angel inside the bush, which blew my mind, since most depictions (Prince of Egypt, Ten Commandments movie, drawings) don‚Äôt show this. In my looking so far, the angel of Yahweh (maybe all angels?) has either had a human form described, or else no visual description, but I don‚Äôt know for sure. I certainly had always pictured the bush like in the movies, but then started to wonder when thinking about the 4th man in the fire that did not burn up Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego, and then it felt almost scandalous comprehending the episode in Exodus 24 when the seventy elders of Israel go up the mountain with Moses, Aaron, and his sons, and ‚Äúthey saw the God of Israel; and under his feet like a pavement of sapphire... Yet he did not reach out his hand against the nobles... and they saw God, and they ate and drank.‚Äù It felt... wrong... for them to see God with feet and hands, but I had to assume my conceptions were just wrong, maybe even the burning bush movie version. We certainly get a multifaceted view of God in the Bible, who is unchanging yet constantly surprising and uncontainable... ‚ÄúWill God indeed dwell on the earth? Behold, the heavens and the heaven of heavens cannot contain you...‚Äù (1 Kings 8:27)

searchDocs.title: Deuteronomy 24-27 & Psalm 61
searchDocs.content: Many of these recent laws feel like they are answering Cain‚Äôs question from Gen 4: "Am I my brother‚Äôs keeper?" I wonder if this was some of the seed of imagination in Jesus responding to "Who is my neighbor?"

searchDocs.title: Deuteronomy 30-31 & Psalm 63
searchDocs.content: A thought on 30:11 (‚Äúnot too difficult nor far away‚Äù): It feels related to 29:29 ‚ÄúThe secret things belong to the Lord our God, but the things revealed belong to us, and to our sons forever, so that we may follow all the words of this Torah‚Äù and 30:12 ‚ÄúIt is not in the heavens... nor beyond the sea... but the word is very near you, in your mouth and in your heart that you. may follow it‚Äù I think there is a subtlety to the Torah, us failing it, and Jesus fulfilling it. Genesis indicates that our human vocation is to be the Lord‚Äôs partners on earth, and his covenants like this are not inscrutable or undoable (the plain reading of 30:11). Yet we humans didn‚Äôt fulfill them, Jesus did, we still don‚Äôt, yet we still must (Matt 5:20) by his power and example (Phil 2:5). Somehow these are all true, even if they rub against our various traditions‚Äô systems of interpretation of human nature and how God ‚Äúlogically‚Äù must work.

searchDocs.title: Genesis 16-18 & Psalm 5
searchDocs.content: Of the slaves Abram acquired in Egypt as a result of mistreating his wife, is Hagar (the stranger / the immigrant). She "took" and "gave" her "to her husband" (Genesis 3). Hagar starts to feel superior to Sarai. Abram "solves" this by saying "your" slave woman is "in your hand. Do to her what is good in your eyes." This results in Sarai abusing Hagar. Right after this, Yahweh appears to Abram, saying "walk before me and be blameless" which is not what he had just done. But God establishes an everlasting covenant. The sign of this covenant is a sensitive one for all the males, in the area they make life, after Abram and Sarai had taken advantage of a woman in a vulnerable life situation. When the 3 men / Yahweh appear to Abraham, and Abraham intercedes for Sodom, he appeals to Yahweh as the "judge of all the land" who should do justice. Even as Abraham fears overstepping his bounds, Yahweh concedes every grace Abraham asks for. There is no bargaining happening. But Yahweh hears the outcry from Sodom and Gomorrah and will act on behalf of those crying out.

searchDocs.title: Exodus 10-12 & Psalm 20
searchDocs.content: Regarding the exclusion of foreigners from Passover, a couple ideas... It notes that a foreigner can be circumcised with his household and then ‚Äúcome near‚Äù (temple language) and observe Passover. Passover marks the beginning of the new calendar before they head to Sinai and enter the covenant. That covenant begins with ten ‚Äúcommandments‚Äù (literally ‚Äúten words‚Äù), the first of which is ‚ÄúI am Yahweh your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt, out of the house of slavery.‚Äù Passover is the divine rescue that is the basis for the covenant, so only participants in the covenant can observe it. There is a case to be made that Jesus gave Communion as a Passover parallel (he called this ritual meal a new covenant, and the timing...), Paul treats it seriously, and we rightly give it reverence. It‚Äôs open to all, but only after joining that covenant, same as for Passover. Lev 10:10 to Aaron (priests) ‚ÄúYou are to distinguish between the holy and the common.‚Äù Practicing distinction is essential to priesthood. Radically, Israel is also to be a kingdom of priests, and even more radically, apparently foreigners can join, if they take the terms of the covenant. Just as the Passover was an unconditioned gift to redeem Israel that led to a covenant with conditions (but open to all who will accept them), Jesus‚Äôs sacrifice is an unconditioned gift that leads us to a new covenant, open to all who will accept the terms of his new covenant.

searchDocs.title: Genesis 32-34 & Psalm 10
searchDocs.content: Translation hides the fact that "angel" is just the word "messenger." Messengers of God meet Jacob, and Jacob sends messengers to Esau. God meeting Jacob will parallel Jacob meeting Esau. It struck me that Jacob's plans to send gifts ahead to Esau ("And behold,[Jacob] also is behind us") the day before he meets him is with the reasoning in fear: "Then afterward I will see his face; perhaps he will accept me." But then, following the wrestling with God, he says "I have seen God faceto face, yet my life has been spared." ("But he himself passed on ahead of them") on his way to his brother. Even though he sends his family in reverse order of his own favoritism, he puts himself last by going first, maybe with some new boldness that if he can see God face to face and be spared, maybe he can see Esau's face and be spared. That resonates with some deep need for wildness. I'd rather have God hold my shoulders and give a firm shake to get my attention than to be gently ignored. The episodes of preparing to meet and actually meeting Esau is separated by wrestling with God. You can feel the suspense as he's by himself awaiting the reckoning with his past, which is when God shows up to Jacob. To me it felt like a constrast with Abraham's two covenant encounters with God (15 & 17) separated by disastrous mistreatment of Hagar (16) who herself gets a visit from the messenger of Yahweh. In other random thoughts, I've long held that America is not a "Christian nation" because it confuses worldly power for the self-giving way of Jesus. And I do think it's vital not to read America into the Bible, or ancient Israel, and certainly not the church. But today I wondered, with the confusion about who we are as a country, whether there is a place for envisioning America hopefully as patterned in its architecture after a Judeo-Christian Exodus structure whose pluralism is inherent in that patterning itself. Judaic: Founded on laws that order society for a common good and protect the quartet of the vulnerable: widows, orphans, foreigners, & the poor.Christian: Founded on a belief in a new way to be human (where real power is in serving) and pluralist because that new way to be human speaks for itself without coercion.A nation of Exodus: Simultaneously a people set free, a refuge for those seeking liberty, and a body infected with injustice in need of constant reform.

searchDocs.title: Genesis 46-47 & Psalm 15
searchDocs.content: 70 people from the house of Jacob (numbering the men) come to Egypt who will become a new nation out of the 70 nations divided at Babylon. It "rhymes" with Deuteronomy 32:8-9: When the Most High gave the nations their inheritance, When he separated the sons of adam, He set the boundaries of the peoples According to the number of the sons of elohim. For Yahweh's portion is his people; Jacob is the allotment of his inheritance." Note: Some translations incorrectly say "according to the number of the sons of Israel." The table of 70 nations after the tower of Babylon is followed by Yahweh calling Abram out as the start of a new nation. Now, his descendants are nominally 70 as the response to human (sons of adam) and divine (sons of elohim) rebellion and division, and the vehicle of future blessing of all those nations (Genesis 12:3), but not the sons of elohim (Psalm 82 6-8): In you all the families of the ground (adamah) will be be blessed I said, you are gods, And all of you are sons of the Most High. Nevertheless you will die like men (adam), And fall (niphalu, a verb form of nephilim) like one of the princes. Arise, elohim, judge the land! For you possess all the nations. 70 people is small next to 70 nations. Maybe this is part of why, along with Isaiah's suffering servant and of course Jesus being "lifted up" as king by being put on a cross of shame, it's natural for Paul to say: God has chosen the weak things of the world to shame the things which are strong, and the insignificant things of the world and the despised God has chosen. With Psalm 15 in mind, this is more than a mere Cinderella story; these chosen will have a weighty responsibility to be able to "settle on Yahweh's holy hill."

searchDocs.title: Genesis 1-3 & Psalm 1
searchDocs.content: I've spent a lot of time in the last few years learning about the ancient context of the Hebrew Bible, and the ancient Near East worldview of the three-tiered cosmos. It's now hard to not see it in Genesis 1 now. I've also learned maybe fifty Hebrew words and benefited from un-translating select words from Genesis 1-11. What jumps out at me now is about the serpent (nachash) and the tree of knowing good and bad. The nachash doesn't strictly utter any false propositions: "Did elohim actually say, 'You shall not eat of any tree in the garden'?" It's just a question, not a statement."You will not surely die." She didn't die. No mention of consequences."For elohim knows that in the day you eat of it your eyes will be opened, and you will be like elohim, knowing good and bad." She is already like elohim (Genesis 1), and she would "know" good and bad,experientially The nachash lies while uttering no technically false statements. The nachash even uses language from Yahweh's command that Eve does not quote: surely diein the day you eat of it The nachash never utters Yahweh's name, but always uses "elohim." Eve saw that the tree was: Good for foodA delight to the eyesDesirable for wisdom And she took Wisdom is desirable and surely Yahweh wanted the humans to have it, so that they could rule properly as his images. How were they intended to get it? In the language of the narrative, maybe the tree of knowing good and bad wasthe means of acquiring wisdom to judge between good and bad, but the proper way to acquire it was to obey and not eat of it. Was the tree guaranteed to give knowledge of good and bad one way or another? Either through experience by eating of it in disobedience, or through wisdom by obeying in trust? "The fear of Yahweh is the beginning of wisdom" according to Psalms and Proverbs. Apparently the right way to "know" good and bad is a process that starts with trusting and obeying Yahweh, whereas seeing and taking can cause "knowing" it experientially, and painfully quickly.

searchDocs.title: Genesis 48-50 & Psalm 16
searchDocs.content: I've always loved "you meant evil for me, but God meant it for good in order... to keep many people alive." God used what people meant for evil to make known through Joseph the way of life through the famine. Profound in the story, with a cosmic ring to it.

searchDocs.title: Genesis 12-15 & Psalm 4
searchDocs.content: The means of blessing to all the earth's families is revealed through a specific call to obedience by Abram, and he obeys, kind of. "Go from your country and from your relatives..." "and Lot went with him." Then Abram goes to Egypt and gets wealth and life at the expense of Sarai ("that I may live on account of you") rather than getting life via trust in the Lord (Genesis 3 again, even with Sarai: saw-beautiful-took). Abram's lack of trust means Yahweh even has to bring harm to Pharaoh who seems innocent here, for the sake of his promise to Abram. But Abram does a repeat and "called on the name of Yahweh" at the same spot as before Egypt, but actions from lack of trust will still cause him problems: Lot: strife between herdsmen"gifts" from Pharaoh that make Abram wealthy, including female servants, including Hagar, whom Abram and Sarai will later abuse. He later refuses gifts from the king of Salem so he can't say "I've made Abram rich." Maybe this is a repentance from letting the king of Egypt do that to him.Lot: Abram has to rescue after the kings of Sodom and Gomorrah fall into tar pits (grim foreshadowing) Psalm 4: "In peace I will both lie down and sleep, for you alone, Lord, have me dwell in safety." Something for me to meditate on when my mind races at night.

searchDocs.title: Genesis 8-11 & Psalm 3
searchDocs.content: Names are apparently very important in Genesis 1-11: The human has the job of naming the animalsThe human names his wifeCain names the first city after his son.Parents name their childrenThe Nephilim (translated "fallen ones") are all about being strong and having a great name.Noah's son Shem (translated "Name") is an ancestor of AbramThe builders of Babylon are all about making a name for themselves, but end up with a confused name.

searchDocs.title: Isaiah 42-44 & Psalm 119:1-32
searchDocs.content: Psalm 119:32: I shall run the way of Your commandments, For You will enlarge my heart. I love this promise of an increase of capacity to keep his commandments, but it requires running that way before getting that heart-enlargement.

searchDocs.title: Genesis 4-7 & Psalm 2
searchDocs.content: Today's video succinctly summarizes the pattern of seeing something good and taking, and its results. It's hard to not see now, like with the rebellion of the spiritual beings in Genesis 6: they "saw" that the daughters of humanity were "good" and "took" resulting in mighty men who make their own name great and cause problems later in the promised land. The part that keeps pulling on my heart, though, is from Genesis 4. Yes, I am my brother's keeper. It's a natural extension of the Genesis 1-2 ideal. And Psalm 2 adds a cosmic scope to it: the nations and the ends of the earth in the kingdom of the Lord's messiah.

searchDocs.title: Genesis 32-34 & Psalm 12
searchDocs.content: The Judah/Er/Onan/Tamar story is definitely strange, and I've heard colorful conclusions about the story's meaning jumped to in the past. This time I tried to pay attention to repetition to see if anything popped. NASB gives some help about where English translation is sometimes smoothing over repeated words. Judah "went down" from his brothers to find his wifeEr, Judah's firstborn "was evil in the sight of Yahweh, so Yahweh took his life." No explanation about what he did that was evil.Judah tells #2 Onan to perform his duty to "raise up a seed" for his brother. This is the command in Deuteronomy 25:5-10; if not followed, the widow was to spit in his face and publicly shame the brother.Onan knew that "the seed would not be his" so he spilled "on the ground" so that he would not "give a seed" to his brother.This was "evil in the sight of Yahweh, so he took his life also."Judah doesn't honor what would be codified in Deuteronomy 25:5 for #3 Shelah and eventually Tamar seems to be vindicated. "Went down" / "on the ground" contrasts with "raise up a seed." Er, Onan, and Judah all fail with increasing details given, and Tamar gets a strange honor at the end. Given Judah's role in the messianic line and the focus on "the seed" it feels like the plot conflict is that the seed (tying back to Genesis 3:15) is not going to be "raised up" due to the moral failure of 3 men, so a woman steps in and makes it happen. Was that the "right" thing to do? The narrator doesn't tell us, and leaves us scratching our heads about the perversions, but the plot conflict gets resolved, and their son Perez ends up an ancestor of the Lion of the tribe of Judah.

searchDocs.title: Judges 13-15 & Psalm 74
searchDocs.content: The Sampson story so far reads to me like a perfect capturing of testosterone-fueled power unconstrained by wisdom. His first wife is ‚Äúright in his eyes.‚Äù (Genesis 3 warning ‚ö†Ô∏è) Yet it was somehow ‚Äúof the Lord‚Äù who was ‚Äúseeking an occasion against the Philistines.‚Äù A riddle there. The Philistine men use their women to get things from other men, and their neighbors are fine with this unless one miscalculates and gets everyone‚Äôs fields burned; then they burn him and his daughter he used. Samson‚Äôs parents seem like they are trying to follow the Lord‚Äôs instruction, but before Samson‚Äôs birth, his dad doesn‚Äôt get the hints that the angel of the Lord seems more interested in speaking to his mom and giving her a special task, than to him.

searchDocs.title: Numbers 35-36 & Psalm 52
searchDocs.content: One interesting thing is the first mention of the cities of refuge for non-premeditated or possibly accidental killers. Numbers 35:24 ‚Äúthen the congregation shall judge between the one who fatally struck the victim and the blood avenger‚Äù We take for granted that even murderers get trials, with presumed innocence until proven guilty. But that‚Äôs the gift of a legal tradition we‚Äôve inherited. Many ancient cultures assumed vigilante justice, but here a big limit gets put on it. It also echoes what comes after the first murder in Genesis, when the Lord sets a sign for Cain ‚Äúso that no one finding him would kill him.‚Äù The refuge cities function like Cain‚Äôs sign. Another parallel with Genesis 4: ‚Äúyou are cursed from the ground which has opened its mouth to receive your brother‚Äôs blood from your hand.‚Äù And Numbers ‚Äúblood defiles the land... So you shall not defile the land in which you live, in the midst of which I dwell.‚Äù

searchDocs.title: Judges 6-8 & Psalm 72
searchDocs.content: Gideon, with the fleece üêë, uses language similar to Abraham ‚Äúbargaining‚Äù for Sodom (which was held up as an honorable thing to do) but here tests God multiple times, literally violating Deuteronomy 6:16. How easy it is to fall into using Bible-ish talk to do what‚Äôs right in our own eyes.

searchDocs.title: Numbers 14-16 & Psalm 44
searchDocs.content: The ordering of commands and narrative today messed with me. I was enjoying the bit about the violet thread at the corner of the Israelites‚Äô clothes as a reminder to see with the eyes of heaven as they went about their day-to-day. A little thread of tabernacle for every member of the kingdom of priests. Anachronistically, this feels a bit ‚Äúdemocratic‚Äù. Probably a lot more beauty for me to think about there... But then comes the rebellion of some of the Levites, and it feels like they are using this symbolism with the violet threads that brings a bit of tabernacle to everyone, to cause trouble. Do they feel threatened that everyone gets some purple thread when the Levites were supposed to be special? Are they jealous of the priesthood and Aaron and Moses, a subset of the Levites (that seems to be what they are saying more directly)? Whatever it was, they are clearly not happy with their place in the ordering of the nation, and it seems like the symbolism of the violet threads for everyone set them off. Whatever happened with the judgment of the sons of Korah, some must have survived, since many of the Psalms are attributed to the sons of Korah. RE: ‚Äúthird and fourth‚Äù generations. Literally in Hebrew, it‚Äôs ‚Äúto the third and fourth‚Äù (‚Äúgeneration‚Äù implied, but not there literally). ‚Äú3...4‚Äù is a Hebrew turn of phrase, something like ‚Äúa few‚Äù or ‚Äúas much as needed‚Äù and shows up even in poetic couplets like Proverbs 30:18. The handful of generations should be compared to the ‚Äúthousands of generations of those who love me and keep my commandments‚Äù who receive the Lord‚Äôs steadfast love (gracious, compassionate, slow to anger, abounding in steadfast love). Sometimes people repeat their parents‚Äô mistakes/rebellions for a few generations, but the Lord‚Äôs steadfast love is orders of magnitude greater than the effects of those.

searchDocs.title: Numbers 19-21 & Psalm 46
searchDocs.content: Interesting bit: the fiery snakes/bronze snake are the first appearance of the word ‚Äúseraphim‚Äù in the Bible.

searchDocs.title: Numbers 22-24 & Psalm 47
searchDocs.content: I love the Balaam story. It‚Äôs so complex. Somehow he knows about and speaks to Yahweh, yet is not his friend (nor is Yahweh his friend... this is the first time in the story the Hebrew word ‚Äúsatan‚Äù‚Äîadversary, never a proper name‚Äîshows up with Yahweh setting himself as Balaam‚Äôs adversary). Fascinating what Balaam is known for by Balak: ‚Äúhe whom you bless is blessed, and he whom you curse is cursed.‚Äù‚Äîand dark twist on the Lord‚Äôs blessing to Abraham and his descendants. Everyone in this episode is involved in attempting dark mystical death-dealing, but it just crescendoes to blessings on Israel and prophecy of a future (‚Äúnot near‚Äù / ‚Äúnot now‚Äù) king from Israel, despite all this. I don‚Äôt know about the meaning here, but Num 24:1-2 is interesting: ‚ÄúWhen Balaam saw that it pleased the Lord to bless Israel, he did not go as at other times to seek omens, rather he turned his face toward the wilderness. And Balaam raised his eyes and saw Israel... and the Spirit of God came upon him.‚Äù I don‚Äôt know about this, but on this third time where one opposed to the Lord has death-dealing words turned to life, he turns to the wilderness, with the Spirit of God, and points to the Messiah, echoing the blessing to Abraham, as we‚Äôre nearing Deuteronomy. Jesus, after being baptized, was led by the Spirit, into the wilderness, to meet his adversary, who tries to deal death with cursed words, which Jesus rebuts 3 times with words from Deuteronomy. ü§Ø It's also funny that Balaam gives three literall ass-beatings ü´è RE: ‚Äúascended‚Äù in Ps 47:5, this is likely not ancient ignorance of not knowing the Lord is everywhere and not confined to certain places. Biblical positional language about ascending and descending is not a 2 or 3D literal thing. Similarly, geography isn‚Äôt always either (Ps 48:2 Zion isn‚Äôt literally in the far north, but it is in terms of cosmic significance... but that‚Äôs a whole rabbit trail about digs at Baal). Ancient chief gods were said to ascend and ride clouds and such, so Biblical language to that effect for the Lord signifies in a way that makes cultural sense that, yes, he has all the power and glory, but pay attention to all the ways that the Lord is quite distinct from the gods, now that we‚Äôve got your attention with this deity symbolism you Ancient Near Easterners know all about.

searchDocs.title: Numbers 8-10 & Psalm 42
searchDocs.content: Psalm 42:1-2 reminds me of Peter saying to Jesus: ‚ÄúWho can we go to? You have the words of everlasting life.‚Äù V3 probably refers to human enemies or ‚Äúthe nations.‚Äù This question, ‚ÄúWhere is your God?‚Äùcomes from those two subjects in a handful of other places in the Hebrew Bible, but in v3, the word ‚Äúthey‚Äù isn‚Äôt even in the Hebrew. The last verse is beautiful: Why are you in despair, my soul? And why are you restless within me? Wait for God, for I will again praise Him For the ‚Äúyeshua‚Äù of His presence, my God.

searchDocs.title: Ruth & Psalm 77
searchDocs.content: Ruth: We thought you could use a story with a happy ending after reading basically Pulp Fiction. It does make sense of why everyone is so concerned constantly about Ruth being assaulted. Judges did feel a bit like ‚ÄúBook of Eli‚Äù Bible Project is fond of calling the Prophets (incl Judges) a ‚Äúminority report‚Äù of the Israelites who weren‚Äôt numerically representative of all ancient Israel, but were eventually recognized after the exile hit and people realized they‚Äôd been right. ‚ÄúIn the time of the Judges‚Äù now activates something in me like ‚ÄúIn the land of Mordor where the shadows lie‚Äù does. Judges... #triggerwarning üòÖ

searchDocs.title: Getting Started‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Get started by creating a new site. Or try Docusaurus immediately with docusaurus.new.

searchDocs.title: What you'll need‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Node.js version 16.14 or above: When installing Node.js, you are recommended to check all checkboxes related to dependencies.

searchDocs.title: Generate a new site‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Generate a new Docusaurus site using the classic template. The classic template will automatically be added to your project after you run the command: npm init docusaurus@latest my-website classic  You can type this command into Command Prompt, Powershell, Terminal, or any other integrated terminal of your code editor. The command also installs all necessary dependencies you need to run Docusaurus.

searchDocs.title: Start your site‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Run the development server: cd my-website npm run start  The cd command changes the directory you're working with. In order to work with your newly created Docusaurus site, you'll need to navigate the terminal there. The npm run start command builds your website locally and serves it through a development server, ready for you to view at http://localhost:3000/. Open docs/intro.md (this page) and edit some lines: the site reloads automatically and displays your changes.

searchDocs.title: Build your site‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Build your site for production: npm run build  The static files are generated in the build folder.

searchDocs.title: Deploy your site‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Test your production build locally: npm run serve  The build folder is now served at http://localhost:3000/. You can now deploy the build folder almost anywhere easily, for free or very small cost (read the Deployment Guide).

searchDocs.title: What's next?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Read the official documentationModify your site configuration with docusaurus.config.jsAdd navbar and footer items with themeConfigAdd a custom Design and LayoutAdd a search barFind inspirations in the Docusaurus showcaseGet involved in the Docusaurus Community

searchDocs.title: Create your first Post‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Create a file at blog/2021-02-28-greetings.md: blog/2021-02-28-greetings.md --- slug: greetings title: Greetings! authors: - name: Joel Marcey title: Co-creator of Docusaurus 1 url: https://github.com/JoelMarcey image_url: https://github.com/JoelMarcey.png - name: S√©bastien Lorber title: Docusaurus maintainer url: https://sebastienlorber.com image_url: https://github.com/slorber.png tags: [greetings] --- Congratulations, you have made your first post! Feel free to play around and edit this post as much you like.  A new blog post is now available at http://localhost:3000/blog/greetings.

searchDocs.title: Create your first Doc‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Create a Markdown file at docs/hello.md: docs/hello.md # Hello This is my **first Docusaurus document**!  A new document is now available at http://localhost:3000/docs/hello.

searchDocs.title: Configure the Sidebar‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Docusaurus automatically creates a sidebar from the docs folder. Add metadata to customize the sidebar label and position: docs/hello.md --- sidebar_label: 'Hi!' sidebar_position: 3 --- # Hello This is my **first Docusaurus document**!  It is also possible to create your sidebar explicitly in sidebars.js: sidebars.js module.exports = { tutorialSidebar: [ 'intro', 'hello', { type: 'category', label: 'Tutorial', items: ['tutorial-basics/create-a-document'], }, ], };

searchDocs.title: Create your first React Page‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Create a file at src/pages/my-react-page.js: src/pages/my-react-page.js import React from 'react'; import Layout from '@theme/Layout'; export default function MyReactPage() { return ( <Layout> <h1>My React page</h1> <p>This is a React page</p> </Layout> ); }  A new page is now available at http://localhost:3000/my-react-page.

searchDocs.title: Create your first Markdown Page‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Create a file at src/pages/my-markdown-page.md: src/pages/my-markdown-page.md # My Markdown page This is a Markdown page  A new page is now available at http://localhost:3000/my-markdown-page.

searchDocs.title: Create a docs version‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Release a version 1.0 of your project: npm run docusaurus docs:version 1.0  The docs folder is copied into versioned_docs/version-1.0 and versions.json is created. Your docs now have 2 versions: 1.0 at http://localhost:3000/docs/ for the version 1.0 docscurrent at http://localhost:3000/docs/next/ for the upcoming, unreleased docs

searchDocs.title: Add a Version Dropdown‚Äã
searchDocs.content: To navigate seamlessly across versions, add a version dropdown. Modify the docusaurus.config.js file: docusaurus.config.js module.exports = { themeConfig: { navbar: { items: [ { type: "docsVersionDropdown", }, ], }, }, };  The docs version dropdown appears in your navbar:

searchDocs.title: Update an existing version‚Äã
searchDocs.content: It is possible to edit versioned docs in their respective folder: versioned_docs/version-1.0/hello.md updates http://localhost:3000/docs/hellodocs/hello.md updates http://localhost:3000/docs/next/hello

searchDocs.title: Configure i18n‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Modify docusaurus.config.js to add support for the fr locale: docusaurus.config.js module.exports = { i18n: { defaultLocale: "en", locales: ["en", "fr"], }, };

searchDocs.title: Translate a doc‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Copy the docs/intro.md file to the i18n/fr folder: mkdir -p i18n/fr/docusaurus-plugin-content-docs/current/ cp docs/intro.md i18n/fr/docusaurus-plugin-content-docs/current/intro.md  Translate i18n/fr/docusaurus-plugin-content-docs/current/intro.md in French.

searchDocs.title: Start your localized site‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Start your site on the French locale: npm run start -- --locale fr  Your localized site is accessible at http://localhost:3000/fr/ and the Getting Started page is translated. caution In development, you can only use one locale at a same time.

searchDocs.title: Add a Locale Dropdown‚Äã
searchDocs.content: To navigate seamlessly across languages, add a locale dropdown. Modify the docusaurus.config.js file: docusaurus.config.js module.exports = { themeConfig: { navbar: { items: [ { type: "localeDropdown", }, ], }, }, };  The locale dropdown now appears in your navbar:

searchDocs.title: Build your localized site‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Build your site for a specific locale: npm run build -- --locale fr  Or build your site to include all the locales at once: npm run build

searchDocs.title: Front Matter‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Markdown documents have metadata at the top called Front Matter: my-doc.md --- id: my-doc-id title: My document title description: My document description slug: /my-custom-url --- ## Markdown heading Markdown text with [links](./hello.md)

searchDocs.title: Links‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Regular Markdown links are supported, using url paths or relative file paths. Let's see how to [Create a page](/create-a-page).  Let's see how to [Create a page](./create-a-page.md).  Result: Let's see how to Create a page.

searchDocs.title: Images‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Regular Markdown images are supported. You can use absolute paths to reference images in the static directory (static/img/docusaurus.png): ![Docusaurus logo](/img/docusaurus.png)  You can reference images relative to the current file as well. This is particularly useful to colocate images close to the Markdown files using them: ![Docusaurus logo](./img/docusaurus.png)

searchDocs.title: Code Blocks‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Markdown code blocks are supported with Syntax highlighting. ```jsx title="src/components/HelloDocusaurus.js" function HelloDocusaurus() { return ( <h1>Hello, Docusaurus!</h1> ) } ```  src/components/HelloDocusaurus.js function HelloDocusaurus() { return <h1>Hello, Docusaurus!</h1>; }

searchDocs.title: Admonitions‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Docusaurus has a special syntax to create admonitions and callouts: :::tip My tip Use this awesome feature option ::: :::danger Take care This action is dangerous :::  My tip Use this awesome feature option Take care This action is dangerous

searchDocs.title: MDX and React Components‚Äã
searchDocs.content: MDX can make your documentation more interactive and allows using any React components inside Markdown: export const Highlight = ({children, color}) => ( <span style={{ backgroundColor: color, borderRadius: '20px', color: '#fff', padding: '10px', cursor: 'pointer', }} onClick={() => { alert(`You clicked the color ${color} with label ${children}`) }}> {children} </span> ); This is <Highlight color="#25c2a0">Docusaurus green</Highlight> ! This is <Highlight color="#1877F2">Facebook blue</Highlight> !  This is Docusaurus green ! This is Facebook blue !
